bio:treatment.discussion: Carex sect. Vulpinae is not clearly distinguished from several other sections, especially sect. Multiflorae. Features that generally distinguish sect. Vulpinae from sect. Multiflorae include the presence of spongy tissue in the perigynium bases, the perigynia tapered to a beak, and the cylindric persistent style bases, but there are taxa within each section possessing different combinations of these characters. Within sect. Vulpinae morphologic similarity distinguishes several groups of species. Many eastern taxa and the widely distributed Carex stipata have elongated inflorescences, hyaline scales, perigynium bases distended by spongy tissue, and at least one conspicuous setaceous bract (although C. alopecoidea and C. conjuncta lack distended perigynium bases). The western taxa have very condensed inflorescences with brown scales, perigynia that are not basally distended, and scalelike bracts. Among the western species, C. neurophora and C. nervina are morphologically very similar, appear to have a recent common origin, and are strongly differentiated from C. jonesii by vegetative morphology.

key_statement.description: Inflorescences very condensed, globose to ovoid or shortly cylindric; proximal branches not distinguishable and proximal internode not visible, to 3 mm; bracts scalelike, not visible.
Leaves clustered at base; proximal sheaths with long blades, fronts hyaline; perigynium
Leaves not clustered at base; proximal sheaths with short blades, fronts herbaceous; perigynium beak smooth or scabrous.
Distal sheath fronts smooth, apex coriaceous, concave; perigynium beak smooth
Distal sheath fronts rugose, apex hyaline, convex; perigynium beak scabrous
Inflorescences elongated, cylindric; proximal branches distinguishable and proximal internode usually visible, usually more than 3 mm; at least proximal bracts setaceous, apparent.
Apex of sheath front yellow, thickened, not fragile; leaf blades papillose adaxially
Apex of sheath front not yellow, thin, usually fragile; leaf blades not papillose.
Larger perigynia 6–8 mm, prominently distended at base and forming basal disk;
Perigynia less than 6 mm, prominent basal disk absent, sometimes somewhat distended at base; sheath fronts smooth or rugose, dotted or not.
Perigynia veinless adaxially, not distended at base.
Sheath fronts smooth; achenes circular; perigynia with 3–5 faint veins
Sheath fronts rugose; achenes ovate; perigynia with 3–5 prominent veins
Perigynia veined adaxially, distended at base.
Sheath fronts smooth, with tubular extension above blade junction; ligules
Sheath fronts rugose, not forming tubular extension above blade junction; ligules to 10 mm; culms easily compressed, proximal sheaths usually with
